channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan: Striking image captures Kabul exodus
item.description: A photo appears to show hundreds of Afghans packed on a US military plane as they flee the Taliban.

item.title: New Zealand enters nationwide lockdown over one Covid case
item.description: Authorities say they are still running tests, but are assuming it is a case of the Delta variant.

item.title: France wildfire: Thousands evacuated as blaze rages near Riviera
item.description: Firefighters clear campsites in the Var region as some 5,000 hectares are destroyed by fire.

item.title: Sudoku: Maki Kaji, puzzle enthusiast, dies aged 69
item.description: The Japanese puzzle enthusiast helped popularise the number game, leading to its global success.

item.title: Bob Dylan denies sexually abusing girl in 1965
item.description: A woman says the US singer-songwriter abused her when she was 12 - a claim he says is untrue.

item.title: Israel battles huge wildfire near Jerusalem
item.description: The blaze has destroyed some 2,000 hectares (5,000 acres) of forest over the past three days.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Tropical Storm Grace hampers rescue
item.description: Tropical Storm Grace has dumped heavy rain on Haiti just days after a tremor left at least 1,419 dead.

item.title: Images show decline of California's 'life source'
item.description: Justin Sullivan has been following California's second-largest reservoir's falling water levels.

item.title: Uganda anti-pornography law dropped after backlash
item.description: Legislation branded the "anti-miniskirt" law is annulled by Uganda's Constitutional Court.

item.title: Bezos sues Nasa over its deal with Elon Musk's SpaceX
item.description: Mr Bezos's Blue Origin says it was unfairly treated after being excluded from lunar landing contract.

item.title: US increases food stamp aid for poorer Americans
item.description: The increase of about $36 (£26) per person, per month, is the largest in the programme's history.

item.title: Biden's speech on Afghanistan fact-checked
item.description: How consistent was President Biden's speech with his previous statements on Afghanistan?

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.

item.title: Hakainde Hichilema: The Zambian 'cattle boy' who became president
item.description: After six attempts, Hakainde Hichilema has finally become president of Zambia.

item.title: There and back again: The epic adventures of China's wandering elephants
item.description: After a mammoth journey across the country the pack of pachyderms are finally heading home.

item.title: Would you let a robot lawyer defend you?
item.description: Why artificial intelligence is increasingly being used by the legal profession.

item.title: Will Taliban take country back to past, asks John Simpson
item.description: What sort of nation will Afghanistan be after 2021, asks the BBC's world affairs editor John Simpson.

item.title: Nigeria's Kano state moves to ban mannequin heads on Islamic grounds
item.description: The Islamic police in Kano, Nigeria, say shop dummies with heads symbolise "idolatry" and are banned.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.

item.title: How the Taliban seized Afghanistan again
item.description: Taliban fighters have swept across Afghanistan taking control of towns and cities.

item.title: Afghanistan: Female presenters back on Tolo News after Taliban takeover
item.description: Women had been noticeably absent from major news outlets after the Taliban took control of Afghanistan.

item.title: Joe Biden on Afghanistan: 'I stand squarely behind my decision'
item.description: The US president says the quick collapse of the Afghan government shows why America had to withdraw.

item.title: Malala: 'Futures of Afghan child refugees aren't lost'
item.description: Nobel peace laureate, Malala Yousafzai was shot in the head by the Taliban in 2012.

item.title: UK military commander: 'We've betrayed' Afghans who helped British troops'
item.description: Major General Charlie Herbert, a military commander from the UK’s campaign in Afghanistan, has accused the government of betraying Afghans who supported British troops.

item.title: Does the world now face a new terror threat?
item.description: The Taliban are back, 20 years after being ousted for supporting terror groups. Will they do the same?

item.title: Why is the Taliban's Kabul victory being compared to the fall of Saigon?
item.description: Many have drawn parallels with America's withdrawal from Vietnam in 1975 - but is this fair?

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: How America watched as Taliban 'won' the war
item.description: US military veterans and Afghan Americans reflect on a dramatic day - and the two-decade conflict.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Afghanistan athletes unable to attend Games because of unrest
item.description: Afghanistan's two Paralympic athletes are stropped from competing at the Tokyo Games because of unrest in the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban spokesman Suhail Shaheen calls the BBC - interview in full
item.description: A spokesman for the Taliban, Suhail Shaheen, called the BBC's Yalda Hakim, live on air.

item.title: How the Taliban stormed across Afghanistan in ten days
item.description: The Taliban took their first city on 6 Aug and arrived in Kabul just over a week later.

item.title: Afghanistan: In pictures: Kabul - a day after Taliban takeover
item.description: Kabul - the Afghan capital - is quiet in some parts, but chaotic at the airport where thousands are trying to flee.

item.title: Kabul centre quiet and subdued after Taliban takeover
item.description: BBC video journalist Malik Mudassir speaks about life in the city after its capture by the Taliban.

item.title: Afghanistan: Chaotic scenes at Kabul airport
item.description: Video shows hundreds of Afghans attempting to escape, as the Taliban took over the capital.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'Women won't be silenced by the Taliban'
item.description: Teacher and human rights activist Pashtana Durrani questions what the Taliban are saying on women's rights.

item.title: Afghanistan conflict: The Air India flight out on a fateful Sunday
item.description: Air India's only flight to Kabul on Sunday circled for 90 minutes over the Afghan capital before landing.
